awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Chemically Modified, Plasma-Nanoengineered Graphene Nanopetals for Spontaneous, Self-Powered and Efficient Oil Contamination Remediation
awd_abstract_narration:
Spills and leakage of oil during offshore oil production or marine transportation cause both long-term damage to water ecosystems and loss of valuable resources. Thus, efficient strategies for capturing and treating such releases are urgently required. Gravity-driven siphons allow the transport of liquids between phases. Siphons have been utilized for various applications and hold promise for oil recovery. However, siphon devices generally suffer from significant issues such as low oil removal flow rate, poor stability, and inability to self-restart after disruption of the siphon. The goal of this project is to develop a novel oil skimming technology based on a new chemically modified graphene material. The hydrophobic nature of graphene is expected to result in high remediation efficiency. Experiments guided by computational molecular simulations will provide fundamental understanding of the interaction of oil with graphene nanochannels. Successful completion of this research will help guide the design of spontaneous, self-powered, and continuous oil remediation systems with significantly enhanced efficiency. Such systems would have broad-reaching impact on society by alleviating environmental and human health impacts of spilled oil. 

The overall goal of this research project is to understand the nature of interaction between oil and graphene nanochannels. This will be achieved through experiments designed to elucidate the mechanisms governing the synergistic effects of the nanochannel geometry and surface functionalization of plasma-nanoengineered, vertically standing graphene petal (GP) oil skimmers. Guided by molecular simulation results, researchers will design and demonstrate an oil skimmer system based on chemically modified GPs with controlled morphologies for spontaneous, self-powered, and highly efficient oil spill remediation. The knowledge learned from this research will offer insights into developing unique graphene materials to address pressing oil pollution issues. The design principles will also accelerate broader applications of graphene materials to other environmental applications such as seawater desalination, wastewater treatment, and soil and air pollution prevention and remediation. The project will also include significant educational activities, including research programs for local K-12 students, teachers, and undergraduates. Society will benefit from students acquiring relevant knowledge and skills to diversify and train the STEM workforce of the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Oil spills and leakage accidents during offshore oil production or marine transportation have not only caused severe and long-term damage to water ecosystems but also led to a great loss of valuable resources. The project provides a novel oil skimming strategy featured by solar-heating, new graphene petal (GP) nanostructures, capillary siphon-coupled and one-step oil contamination remediation without external energy input from devices such as pumps, squeezers/centrifuges or heaters, which reduces overall energy consumption and economic costs. The integrated molecular simulations and uniquely designed experiments reveal new mechanisms of oil-graphene interaction during oil transport in nanochannels. By tuning physical parameters of nanochannels and chemically modifying GP surfaces, spontaneous, continuous, and self-powered oil contamination remediation has been achieved with a 5 to 8X increase in oil flow rate compared to our initial devices. For instance, outdoor tests of GP oil skimmers demonstrated a peak rate of 938.2 L m−2 h−1 at noon and a remarkable daily collection of 14,001 L m−2, achieved without external power or human intervention. Notably, the oil flow flux was calculated to be 207,218 L m−2 h−1 bar−1, even outpacing conventional pump-assisted devices. Our research results have been substantial, leading to the publication of 15 peer-reviewed journal papers. Additionally, our findings and methodologies have been shared with the wider scientific community through communications with peers at international conferences such as Materials Research Society (MRS). These outcomes of the project garnered significant interest and recognition in the field. 

The broader impact of the NSF project stretches beyond the fundamental research. The results of this project may contribute to improving the remediation efficiency of oil-contaminated water. The mechanisms of oil transport in graphene nanochannels understood may pave the road for further studies in this field, which accelerates broader applications of graphene to other environmental engineering fields such as seawater desalination, wastewater treatment, and soil and air pollution prevention. The proposed research will also generate systematic, insightful techniques of controlling the physical and chemical properties of graphene structures for efficient oil contamination remediation. The knowledge obtained from this project will have direct impact on alleviating long-term damage of spilled oil to water ecosystems in heavily polluted areas. Moreover, the scalable fabrication of graphene oil skimmers promises future industrial applications. The oil industry will also benefit from the success of this project as abundant oil can be recovered to minimize the loss in oil transportation.

Moreover, a significant focus of our project was on the educational and training aspects, where we actively engaged with students from the University of Notre Dame. Two graduate students at UND participated in this project through opportunities such as simulation algorithm development and computational studies. The project generated a significant impact on the PI’s teaching and educational experiences in his undergraduate- and graduate-level classes at UND. Specifically, the modules on solar-enhanced oil transport involving thermodynamics served as valuable enhancements to Luo’s undergraduate thermodynamics courses. The knowledge introduced students to the real-world applications of renewable solar energy and nanotechnology in solving global environmental issues. Our educational goal is to cultivate the interests of the young generation in STEM fields, particularly the traditionally underrepresented minorities and groups, in the areas of nanofluid transport, thermal transport, energy and materials, help them to acquire relevant knowledge and skills, and train the workforce of the future.
